body.p: “Saw “,” October 14th “,” a snake at Ball’s Hill “,” like a striped snake “,” but apparently yellow-spotted above and with a flatter head? Notied a little snake “,” eight or nine inches long “,” in the rut in the road in the Lincoln woods. It was brown above with a paler-brown dorsal stripe “,” which was bounded on each side by a row of dark-brown or blackish dots one eighth inch apart “,” the opposite rows alternating thus: [image] beneat “,” light cream-color or yellowish white. Evidently Storer’s Coluber ordinatus. It ran along in the deep sandy rut and would probably be over there.”
PE 14, pg. 223/ 9 July 1858-9 November 1858 / NNPM MA 1302:33 / T vol. # XXVII / PDF # XVII / JXI
